SENT.plain: Wallenberg's syndrome is one of the most common clinically recognized conditions due to brain stem infarct, which can nowadays be identified by modern neuro-imaging techniques
We describe a patient complaining of miosis, dysphonia, and dysphagia followed by ataxia
An MRI evaluation was performed including diffusion-weighted imaging, apparent diffusion coefficient, T2-weighted images, fluid attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) and perfusion
A brief discussion of imaging findings is presented as well as a clinical correlation of the symptoms with the anatomic location of the lesion
This case report emphasizes the importance of imaging findings and their clinical correlation with neurological examination
